title: pcb

Process Control Block (PCB)

The PCB is a data structure maintained by the OS for each process. It stores essential process-related information, including:

  • Process ID (PID) â€“ Unique identifier.
  • Process State â€“ Ready, Running, Waiting, etc.
  • CPU Registers â€“ Stored during context switches.
  • Program Counter (PC) â€“ Tracks the next instruction.
  • Memory Information â€“ Page table pointer, heap, stack info.
  • Scheduling Info â€“ Priority, time slice details.
  • I/O & Resource Info â€“ Open files, allocated devices.

Context Switch

A context switch occurs when the CPU switches from one process to another. It involves:

  1. Saving the current process state (registers, PC, etc.) into its PCB.
  2. Loading the new process's state from its PCB.
  3. Updating the CPU registers and resuming execution.

Context Switch & CPU Idle

  • If no process is ready, the CPU enters an idle state (e.g., HALT instruction or low-power mode).
  • The OS wakes the CPU when a process becomes ready (interrupt, new task, etc.).

Yes, the Process Control Block (PCB) typically contains a pointer to the page table or some structure representing the process's virtual memory mapping.

Why?

Since each process has its own virtual address space, the OS needs a way to map virtual addresses to physical memory. The PCB helps by storing:

  • Page table base address (PTBR) â€“ Points to the process's page table in memory.
  • Memory limits â€“ Defines the allocated memory range for the process.
  • Swap space details â€“ If paging is used, it may include swap space info.

This allows the OS to efficiently switch between processes by loading the correct page table when a context switch happens.
